trans-unit.source: Deploy and manage backup for Azure VMs using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy and manage backup for Azure VMs using PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy and manage Azure Backup using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Deploy and manage backup for Azure VMs using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Deploy and manage backup for Azure VMs using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use Azure PowerShell for backup and recovery of Azure IaaS VMs.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use Azure PowerShell for backup and recovery of Azure IaaS VMs.

trans-unit.source: Concepts
trans-unit.target: Concepts

trans-unit.source: Get [introduced to Azure IaaS VM backup](backup-azure-vms-introduction.md) in the Azure Backup documentation.
trans-unit.target: Get [introduced to Azure IaaS VM backup](backup-azure-vms-introduction.md) in the Azure Backup documentation.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] Before you start, ensure that you cover the essentials about the [prerequisites](backup-azure-vms-prepare.md) needed to work with Azure Backup, and the [limitations](backup-azure-vms-prepare.md#limitations) of the current VM backup solution.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] Before you start, ensure that you cover the essentials about the [prerequisites](backup-azure-vms-prepare.md) needed to work with Azure Backup, and the [limitations](backup-azure-vms-prepare.md#limitations) of the current VM backup solution.

trans-unit.source: In order to use PowerShell effectively, it is necessary to understand the hierarchy of objects and from where to start.
trans-unit.target: In order to use PowerShell effectively, it is necessary to understand the hierarchy of objects and from where to start.

trans-unit.source: Object hierarchy
trans-unit.target: Object hierarchy

trans-unit.source: The 2 most important flows are enabling protection for a VM, and restoring data from a recovery point.
trans-unit.target: The 2 most important flows are enabling protection for a VM, and restoring data from a recovery point.

trans-unit.source: The focus of this article is to help you become adept at working with the PowerShell cmdlets to enable these two scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The focus of this article is to help you become adept at working with the PowerShell cmdlets to enable these two scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Setup and Registration
trans-unit.target: Setup and Registration

trans-unit.source: To begin:
trans-unit.target: To begin:

trans-unit.source: [Download latest PowerShell](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/releases) (minimum version required is : 1.0.0)
trans-unit.target: [Download latest PowerShell](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/releases) (minimum version required is : 1.0.0)

trans-unit.source: Find the Azure Backup PowerShell cmdlets available by typing the following command:
trans-unit.target: Find the Azure Backup PowerShell cmdlets available by typing the following command:

trans-unit.source: The following setup and registration tasks can be automated with PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: The following setup and registration tasks can be automated with PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: Create a backup vault
trans-unit.target: Create a backup vault

trans-unit.source: Registering the VMs with the Azure Backup service
trans-unit.target: Registering the VMs with the Azure Backup service

trans-unit.source: Create a backup vault
trans-unit.target: Create a backup vault

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] For customers using Azure Backup for the first time, you need to register the Azure Backup provider to be used with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] For customers using Azure Backup for the first time, you need to register the Azure Backup provider to be used with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: This can be done by running the following command: Register-AzureRmResourceProvider -ProviderNamespace "Microsoft.Backup"
trans-unit.target: This can be done by running the following command: Register-AzureRmResourceProvider -ProviderNamespace "Microsoft.Backup"

trans-unit.source: You can create a new backup vault using the **New-AzureRmBackupVault** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new backup vault using the **New-AzureRmBackupVault** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.
trans-unit.target: The backup vault is an ARM resource, so you need to place it within a Resource Group.

trans-unit.source: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In an elevated Azure PowerShell console, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the **Get-AzureRmBackupVault** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of all the backup vaults in a given subscription using the **Get-AzureRmBackupVault** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] It is convenient to store the backup vault object into a variable.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] It is convenient to store the backup vault object into a variable.

trans-unit.source: The vault object is needed as an input for many Azure Backup cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: The vault object is needed as an input for many Azure Backup cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Registering the VMs
trans-unit.target: Registering the VMs

trans-unit.source: The first step towards configuring backup with Azure Backup is to register your machine or VM with an Azure Backup vault.
trans-unit.target: The first step towards configuring backup with Azure Backup is to register your machine or VM with an Azure Backup vault.

trans-unit.source: The **Register-AzureRmBackupContainer** cmdlet takes the input information of an Azure IaaS virtual machine and registers it with the specified vault.
trans-unit.target: The **Register-AzureRmBackupContainer** cmdlet takes the input information of an Azure IaaS virtual machine and registers it with the specified vault.

trans-unit.source: The register operation associates the Azure virtual machine with the backup vault and tracks the VM through the backup lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: The register operation associates the Azure virtual machine with the backup vault and tracks the VM through the backup lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: Registering your VM with the Azure Backup service creates a top-level container object.
trans-unit.target: Registering your VM with the Azure Backup service creates a top-level container object.

trans-unit.source: A container typically contains multiple items that can be backed up, but in the case of VMs there will be only one backup item for the container.
trans-unit.target: A container typically contains multiple items that can be backed up, but in the case of VMs there will be only one backup item for the container.

trans-unit.source: Backup Azure VMs
trans-unit.target: Backup Azure VMs

trans-unit.source: Create a protection policy
trans-unit.target: Create a protection policy

trans-unit.source: It is not mandatory to create a new protection policy to start backup of your VMs.
trans-unit.target: It is not mandatory to create a new protection policy to start backup of your VMs.

trans-unit.source: The vault comes with a 'Default Policy' that can be used to quickly enable protection, and then edited later with the right details.
trans-unit.target: The vault comes with a 'Default Policy' that can be used to quickly enable protection, and then edited later with the right details.

trans-unit.source: You can get a list of the policies available in the vault by using the **Get-AzureRmBackupProtectionPolicy** cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: You can get a list of the policies available in the vault by using the **Get-AzureRmBackupProtectionPolicy** cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The timezone of the BackupTime field in PowerShell is UTC.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The timezone of the BackupTime field in PowerShell is UTC.

trans-unit.source: However, when the backup time is shown in the Azure portal, the timezone is aligned to your local system along with the UTC offset.
trans-unit.target: However, when the backup time is shown in the Azure portal, the timezone is aligned to your local system along with the UTC offset.

trans-unit.source: A backup policy is associated with at least one retention policy.
trans-unit.target: A backup policy is associated with at least one retention policy.

trans-unit.source: The retention policy defines how long a recovery point is kept with Azure Backup.
trans-unit.target: The retention policy defines how long a recovery point is kept with Azure Backup.

trans-unit.source: The **New-AzureRmBackupRetentionPolicy** cmdlet creates PowerShell objects that hold retention policy information.
trans-unit.target: The **New-AzureRmBackupRetentionPolicy** cmdlet creates PowerShell objects that hold retention policy information.

trans-unit.source: These retention policy objects are used as inputs to the *New-AzureRmBackupProtectionPolicy* cmdlet, or directly with the *Enable-AzureRmBackupProtection* cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: These retention policy objects are used as inputs to the *New-AzureRmBackupProtectionPolicy* cmdlet, or directly with the *Enable-AzureRmBackupProtection* cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: A backup policy defines when and how often the backup of an item is done.
trans-unit.target: A backup policy defines when and how often the backup of an item is done.

trans-unit.source: The **New-AzureRmBackupProtectionPolicy** cmdlet creates a PowerShell object that holds backup policy information.
trans-unit.target: The **New-AzureRmBackupProtectionPolicy** cmdlet creates a PowerShell object that holds backup policy information.

trans-unit.source: The backup policy is used as an input to the *Enable-AzureRmBackupProtection* cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The backup policy is used as an input to the *Enable-AzureRmBackupProtection* cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Enable protection
trans-unit.target: Enable protection

trans-unit.source: Enabling protection involves two objects - the Item and the Policy, and both need to belong to the same vault.
trans-unit.target: Enabling protection involves two objects - the Item and the Policy, and both need to belong to the same vault.

trans-unit.source: Once the policy has been associated with the item, the backup workflow will kick in at the defined schedule.
trans-unit.target: Once the policy has been associated with the item, the backup workflow will kick in at the defined schedule.

trans-unit.source: Initial backup
trans-unit.target: Initial backup

trans-unit.source: The backup schedule will take care of doing the full initial copy for the item and the incremental copy for the subsequent backups.
trans-unit.target: The backup schedule will take care of doing the full initial copy for the item and the incremental copy for the subsequent backups.

trans-unit.source: However, if you want to force the initial backup to happen at a certain time or even immediately then use the **Backup-AzureRmBackupItem** cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: However, if you want to force the initial backup to happen at a certain time or even immediately then use the **Backup-AzureRmBackupItem** cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The timezone of the StartTime and EndTime fields shown in PowerShell is UTC.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The timezone of the StartTime and EndTime fields shown in PowerShell is UTC.

trans-unit.source: However, when the similar information is shown in the Azure portal, the timezone is aligned to your local system clock.
trans-unit.target: However, when the similar information is shown in the Azure portal, the timezone is aligned to your local system clock.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring a backup job
trans-unit.target: Monitoring a backup job

trans-unit.source: Most long-running operations in Azure Backup are modelled as a job.
trans-unit.target: Most long-running operations in Azure Backup are modelled as a job.

trans-unit.source: This makes it easy to track progress without having to keep the Azure portal open at all times.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easy to track progress without having to keep the Azure portal open at all times.

trans-unit.source: To get the latest status of an in-progress job, use the **Get-AzureRmBackupJob** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To get the latest status of an in-progress job, use the **Get-AzureRmBackupJob** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Instead of polling these jobs for completion - which is unnecessary, additional code - it is simpler to use the **Wait-AzureRmBackupJob** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Instead of polling these jobs for completion - which is unnecessary, additional code - it is simpler to use the **Wait-AzureRmBackupJob** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: When used in a script, the cmdlet will pause the execution until either the job completes or the specified timeout value is reached.
trans-unit.target: When used in a script, the cmdlet will pause the execution until either the job completes or the specified timeout value is reached.

trans-unit.source: Restore an Azure VM
trans-unit.target: Restore an Azure VM

trans-unit.source: In order to restore backup data, you need to identify the backed-up Item and the Recovery Point that holds the point-in-time data.
trans-unit.target: In order to restore backup data, you need to identify the backed-up Item and the Recovery Point that holds the point-in-time data.

trans-unit.source: This information is supplied to the Restore-AzureRmBackupItem cmdlet to initiate a restore of data from the vault to the customer's account.
trans-unit.target: This information is supplied to the Restore-AzureRmBackupItem cmdlet to initiate a restore of data from the vault to the customer's account.

trans-unit.source: Select the VM
trans-unit.target: Select the VM

trans-unit.source: To get the PowerShell object that identifies the right backup Item, you need to start from the Container in the vault, and work your way down object hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: To get the PowerShell object that identifies the right backup Item, you need to start from the Container in the vault, and work your way down object hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: To select the container that represents the VM, use the **Get-AzureRmBackupContainer** cmdlet and pipe that to the **Get-AzureRmBackupItem** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To select the container that represents the VM, use the **Get-AzureRmBackupContainer** cmdlet and pipe that to the **Get-AzureRmBackupItem** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Choose a recovery point
trans-unit.target: Choose a recovery point

trans-unit.source: You can now list all the recovery points for the backup item using the **Get-AzureRmBackupRecoveryPoint** cmdlet, and choose the recovery point to restore.
trans-unit.target: You can now list all the recovery points for the backup item using the **Get-AzureRmBackupRecoveryPoint** cmdlet, and choose the recovery point to restore.

trans-unit.source: Typically users pick the most recent *AppConsistent* point in the list.
trans-unit.target: Typically users pick the most recent *AppConsistent* point in the list.

trans-unit.source: The variable ```$rp``` is an array of recovery points for the selected backup item, sorted in reverse order of time - the latest recovery point is at index 0.
trans-unit.target: The variable ```$rp``` is an array of recovery points for the selected backup item, sorted in reverse order of time - the latest recovery point is at index 0.

trans-unit.source: Use standard PowerShell array indexing to pick the recovery point.
trans-unit.target: Use standard PowerShell array indexing to pick the recovery point.

trans-unit.source: For example: ```$rp[0]``` will select the latest recovery point.
trans-unit.target: For example: ```$rp[0]``` will select the latest recovery point.

trans-unit.source: Restoring disks
trans-unit.target: Restoring disks

trans-unit.source: There is a key difference between the restore operations done through the Azure portal and through Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: There is a key difference between the restore operations done through the Azure portal and through Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: With PowerShell, the restore operation stops at restoring the disks and config information from the recovery point.
trans-unit.target: With PowerShell, the restore operation stops at restoring the disks and config information from the recovery point.

trans-unit.source: It does not create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: It does not create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] The Restore-AzureRmBackupItem does not create a VM.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] The Restore-AzureRmBackupItem does not create a VM.

trans-unit.source: It only restores the disks to the specified storage account.
trans-unit.target: It only restores the disks to the specified storage account.

trans-unit.source: This is not the same behavior you will experience in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: This is not the same behavior you will experience in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: You can get the details of the restore operation using the **Get-AzureRmBackupJobDetails** cmdlet once the Restore job has completed.
trans-unit.target: You can get the details of the restore operation using the **Get-AzureRmBackupJobDetails** cmdlet once the Restore job has completed.

trans-unit.source: The *ErrorDetails* property will have the information needed to rebuild the VM.
trans-unit.target: The *ErrorDetails* property will have the information needed to rebuild the VM.

trans-unit.source: Build the VM
trans-unit.target: Build the VM

trans-unit.source: Building the VM out of the restored disks can be done using the older Azure Service Management PowerShell cmdlets, the new Azure Resource Manager templates, or even using the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Building the VM out of the restored disks can be done using the older Azure Service Management PowerShell cmdlets, the new Azure Resource Manager templates, or even using the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: In a quick example, we will show how to get there using the Azure Service Management cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: In a quick example, we will show how to get there using the Azure Service Management cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to build a VM from the restored disks, read about the following cmdlets:
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to build a VM from the restored disks, read about the following cmdlets:

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureDisk
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureDisk

trans-unit.source: New-AzureVMConfig
trans-unit.target: New-AzureVMConfig

trans-unit.source: New-AzureVM
trans-unit.target: New-AzureVM

trans-unit.source: Code samples
trans-unit.target: Code samples

trans-unit.source: 1. Get the completion status of job sub-tasks
trans-unit.target: 1. Get the completion status of job sub-tasks

trans-unit.source: To track the completion status of individual sub-tasks, you can use the **Get-AzureRmBackupJobDetails** cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To track the completion status of individual sub-tasks, you can use the **Get-AzureRmBackupJobDetails** cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: 2. Create a daily/weekly report of backup jobs
trans-unit.target: 2. Create a daily/weekly report of backup jobs

trans-unit.source: Administrators typically want to know what backup jobs ran in the last 24 hours, the status of those backup jobs.
trans-unit.target: Administrators typically want to know what backup jobs ran in the last 24 hours, the status of those backup jobs.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, the amount of data transferred gives administrators a way to estimate their monthly data usage.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, the amount of data transferred gives administrators a way to estimate their monthly data usage.

trans-unit.source: The script below pulls the raw data from the Azure Backup service and displays the information in the PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: The script below pulls the raw data from the Azure Backup service and displays the information in the PowerShell console.

trans-unit.target: If you want to add charting capabilities to this report output, learn from the TechNet blog post [Charting with PowerShell](http://blogs.technet.com/b/richard_macdonald/archive/2009/04/28/3231887.aspx)
